Hi, my name's Krish Kandiah and I'm the president
here at London School of Theology.

4.text:
One of the most frequently asked questions I get
given is around the character and nature of God.

11.text:
Maybe you've heard this quotation from
Richard Dawkins where he reveals his understanding

17.text:
of what God is like? He said "The God of the
Old Testament is arguably the most unpleasant

23.text:
character in all of fiction. Jealous and proud
of it, a petty, unjust, unforgiving control-freak,

30.text:
a vindictive, bloodthirsty, ethnic-cleanser.
A misogynistic, homophobic, racist, infanticidal,

37.text:
genocidal, philicidal, pestilential, megalomaniacal,
sadomasochistic, capriciously malevolent

44.text:
bully." That's how Richard Dawkins understands
the character of God. And I guess I just wanna

50.text:
challenge it on three levels.
First, Richard Dawkins talks about God being

56.text:
a fiction. Now I don't believe that Christianity
is intellectual suicide, I don't think that

62.text:
Christianity is just hoping against hope that
God exists. I believe in scripture, I believe

68.text:
in Jesus because of the evidence put forward.
And I believe that evidence isn't beyond all

73.text:
possible doubt, but I believe it's beyond
reasonable doubt. Let me give you an illustration.

78.text:
You know when you have to go and cross a road,
I don't think it's possible for you to be

84.text:
philosophically certain that you're gonna
make it to the other side. Isn't it possible

88.text:
that as you step out, you step in some superglue
and who knows there might be a nice big steam-roller

96.text:
just inching it's way towards you. Or maybe
those clever guys at Ford have created an invisible

101.text:
car that you can't account for. So even though
you can't be philosophically certain that

107.text:
you're gonna make it to the other side, is
your only other option a leap of blind faith?

112.text:
You're just gonna stick your fingers in your
ears, close your eyes and scream at the top

117.text:
of your voice and just leg it and hope that
you'll make it. I don't think that's your

121.text:
only other option. I think most of us weigh
the evidence up, I think we use our senses

126.text:
and we use our judgement and then we make
an informed step of faith. And that's exactly

133.text:
what the Christian faith is. It's not a belief
in fiction, its an informed step of faith,

139.text:
trusting the evidence that we've got. I think
there's plenty of evidence to demonstrate

144.text:
for example the historical reliability of
the New Testament, of the accounts of Jesus.

149.text:
I think there's a good philosophical reasoning
for why Christianity provides a fantastic

155.text:
explanation of the world that we live in.
So I don't believe Richard Dawkins is right,

160.text:
that this is just a work of fiction.
But the second thing Richard Dawkins seems

166.text:
to have a problem with is the very character
of God, that God is somehow some kind of bully,

171.text:
he's a malevolent evil-spirited person. My
challenge with that is where do we get our

178.text:
standards from by which we can measure God
against? Where does morality get it's basis from?

185.text:
Now I believe that people who don't
have Christian faith who might be atheists

189.text:
or from another faith, I think they can be
very moral people. But I'm not convinced by

195.text:
the moral framework or the moral justification
for that. Let me give you an illustration.

200.text:
I want you to imagine that you handed in a
piece of work that you have worked so hard

206.text:
at, maybe it's your final year dissertation,
maybe it's your A level special project and

211.text:
you worked your socks off. And you've handed
it in early and rather than just leave it

216.text:
in a pigeonhole you've taken it straight to
your tutor. And you hand it in and the cover

221.text:
itself is a thing of beauty, in fact when
your mother saw it she cried because it was

226.text:
so amazing. You hand it in and your tutor
says to you, "Well,

232.text:
thank you for handing that in early, I have some confession to make,
I've never really liked you, in fact I've

239.text:
always felt there was something wrong when
I looked and you, and so because of that I'm

243.text:
gonna give you an F." Now at that stage how
does the conversation go? Well, you know there's no

252.text:
such thing as morality, whatever you choose
to believe is right for you, and what I choose

256.text:
to believe is right for me. Is that the end
of the conversation, is that all you've got?

260.text:
That your morality is internally decided and
therefore you walk away from your tutor saying

265.text:
"Well that was just tough-luck"? I think most
of us in that situation would appeal to something

270.text:
else, we'd say something like, "That's not
fair." And when you appeal to fairness you're

276.text:
appealing to something that stands above you
and your tutor. Where does that come from?

283.text:
So I don't think it's enough to say morality
is just decided internally. I think we believe

287.text:
there's a standard that hangs over all of
us. Well, where could that standard come from?

293.text:
Some people think it comes from majority opinion,
and so you take your case against your tutor

298.text:
to the most democratic tool that you can think
of, you take it to Facebook. And it just so

304.text:
happens that everyone in your college community
is on Facebook and you present your case,

309.text:
but the problem is with Facebook, is well
everyone's gonna be able to see your face

314.text:
and maybe they agree with your tutor, there
is something wrong with the way that you look

317.text:
and so they say "Well he's got a fair point,
we also agree you should get an F." Now if

324.text:
the majority of people on Facebook thought
that, would that make it right? Would that

328.text:
be the end of the conversation, would you
say "Well again just tough luck, the majority

332.text:
was against me?" I think most of us would
appeal still higher. And say morality isn't

338.text:
decided internally, it's not decided by majority
opinion, there are some absolutes here.

344.text:
Now where do those absolutes come from? Where
does the standard come that isn't measured

349.text:
by majority opinion? Christians believe that
comes from God himself. So the interesting

356.text:
thing about Richard Dawkins' challenge to
God is where does he get his standards by

361.text:
which he would measure God? I'm not sure he
has one.

365.text:
And the third challenge for me in Richard
Dawkins' critique of the Christian God is

371.text:
this idea that he's somehow racist, that he's against
certain people, he's judgemental and malevolent.

380.text:
And I wanna challenge that on two levels.
The first, is that I believe in Christianity

386.text:
because of Jesus. I think in Jesus you
get the fullest picture of what God is like.

392.text:
Now that doesn't mean I don't think the Old
Testament has important things to teach me.

397.text:
I just think you get the completeness in Jesus.
Maybe an illustration would help there too.

403.text:
When I was at school I loved science, chemistry
was my favourite subject, and I had an amazing

408.text:
chemistry teacher and he explained to me when
I was doing GCSE's that the atom, the structure

414.text:
of the atom was really easy to understand.
You've got a nucleus which is like a planet,

419.text:
an electron which is like a moon that circles
it, there you go it's as simple as that. And

423.text:
so I understood that and I felt very confident,
and when it came time for A Level chemistry

428.text:
I walked into the classroom feeling like I
understood it. And then we were told, "Oh

433.text:
look that model that was very good for you
when you were at GCSE but we have to tell

436.text:
you a bit more now. You have to think about
maybe a centre and then maybe electron shells

443.text:
around the outside, bit like a matryoshka
doll, getting bigger and bigger as you get

448.text:
further away from the centre." So okay, alright,
I got my head around that one and then with

453.text:
great confidence I walked into my first chemistry
lecture when I did chemistry with medicinal

458.text:
chemistry at university. I remember wearing
my lab coat because I thought you had to wear

462.text:
lab coats to lectures as well as labs back
then. Anyway, we sat there, and our tutor

467.text:
came in and he was very clear, he said "Good
morning" to us all and he spent the rest of

471.text:
the time writing on a white board. And he
started to tell us about Schrodinger's wave

476.text:
equation, he used illustrations like knowing
where an electron is and how much it weighs,

481.text:
well that's like knowing whether a cat is
alive in a fridge. The cat has a suicide cyanide

489.text:
pill with him and if you open the door of
the fridge the cat definitely dies but if

493.text:
you leave the door shut you can't tell whether
the cat is alive or dead. I remember looking

497.text:
around the room, people weeping, not just for
the health and safety of the cat, but for

502.text:
their own understanding of what he was talking
about. So what's happened to me? Did they

509.text:
lie to me at GCSE? Did they deliberately mislead
me at A level? And now we've got this kind

513.text:
of really complex understanding of kind of
wave particle duality at undergraduate level.

520.text:
No, I look back and think actually they were
building a framework that I could better understand

528.text:
how the atom works but they had to start simple
and then build it up gradually. And I think

532.text:
that's what's going on in the Old Testament,
I think God is revealing himself as a God

537.text:
of justice who cannot tolerate any evil. So
therefore there are some very strong punishments

542.text:
when you break God's law. I think God reveals
himself as a God of purity that he won't allow

549.text:
people to worship him in an unhelpful way
and he will stand against evil and injustice

554.text:
and sometimes that will even mean that God's
people in the Old Testament were told to wipe

559.text:
out another nation. And it was all building
a framework to the time I can come to Jesus.

567.text:
And Jesus most perfectly reveals God. And
he reveals a God who is absolutely morally

573.text:
pure and yet still has compassion for the
outcast and for the stranger and for the alien

579.text:
and for the foreigner. And so my understanding
of the Old Testament comes through the lens

584.text:
of understanding who Jesus is. And that's
my basis for knowing that God is not a malevolent

591.text:
bully or a racist. So if you wanna know what
God is like as a Christian I'd say have a

597.text:
look at Jesus. If your view of God is not
Jesus-shaped, you haven't got a Christian

602.text:
understanding of who God is. But I do wanna
encourage you to keep asking these questions.

607.text:
The bible is really clear that God wants us
to worship him with all our hearts, soul and

612.text:
mind. It's not intellectual suicide to become
a Christian, actually it allows your mind

618.text:
to ask the big questions and I think Christianity
provides the best and clearest answers for them.

625.text:
So I hope this helps you on your journey.
All the best, thank you for listening.
